citations.narrative:
Within one of the dog buildings, where dogs were housed, there was a trash container, containing trash without a lid. The
lid was discovered within the building on the other side of a elevated dog enclosure. Trash containers in housing facilities
and in food storage and food preparation areas must be leakproof and must have tightly fitted lids on them at all times.
Corrected at time of the inspection: September 30, 2025.

An adult female dog was housed inside one of the dog buildings, where her primary enclosure was considered the interior
area of the building, the open entry area where elevated whelping enclosures were located and the hall running the length
of the building between the other primary enclosures. Most of which contained dogs. Within this area were several
electrical devices, located on the floor, (i.e. a heater) with electrical cords exposed. Items were stored on shelves within
reach of the dog, which could fall onto the dog. There was a trash container within the area considered the primary
enclosure of the dog with no lid. Primary enclosures must protect dogs from injury. Dogs must be housed within a primary
enclosure that protects them from injury.
To be corrected by October 14, 2025.

An adult female dog with new born puppies was housed within the same primary enclosure as another adult female dog.
Puppies four months or less may not be housed in the same primary enclosure with adult dogs other than their dam.
Housing young puppies with an adult dog that is not their dam can lead to injury or death. The adult dog that is not the
dam must be housed in a different primary enclosure.
Corrected at time of inspection: September 30, 2025

During the routine inspection for records it was noted that 57 of the 149 adult dogs were past due on their annual
parvovirus and distemper vaccination. The dogs ranged from days to months overdue. According to the program of
veterinary care all adult dogs must be vaccinated for parvovirus and distemper annually. Not following the written program
of veterinary care and not maintaining dogs current on required vaccinations can lead to disease and death. The licensee
must follow their program of veterinary care.
To be corrected by October 14, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.1(f) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Within one of the dog buildings, where dogs were housed, there was a trash container, containing trash without a lid. The 
lid was discovered within the building on the other side of a elevated dog enclosure. Trash containers in housing facilities 
and in food storage and food preparation areas must be leakproof and must have tightly fitted lids on them at all times. 
Corrected at time of the inspection: September 30, 2025. 
3.6(a)(2)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
An adult female dog was housed inside one of the dog buildings, where her primary enclosure was considered the interior 
area of the building, the open entry area where elevated whelping enclosures were located and the hall running the length 
of the building between the other primary enclosures. Most of which contained dogs. Within this area were several 
electrical devices, located on the floor, (i.e. a heater) with electrical cords exposed. Items were stored on shelves within 
reach of the dog, which could fall onto the dog. There was a trash container within the area considered the primary 
enclosure of the dog with no lid. Primary enclosures must protect dogs from injury. Dogs must be housed within a primary 
enclosure that protects them from injury. 
To be corrected by October 14, 2025. 
3.7(c) 
   
Compatible grouping. 
An adult female dog with new born puppies was housed within the same primary enclosure as another adult female dog. 
Puppies four months or less may not be housed in the same primary enclosure with adult dogs other than their dam. 
Housing young puppies with an adult dog that is not their dam can lead to injury or death. The adult dog that is not the 
dam must be housed in a different primary enclosure. 
Corrected at time of inspection: September 30, 2025 
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs.

During the routine inspection for records it was noted that 57 of the 149 adult dogs were past due on their annual 
parvovirus and distemper vaccination. The dogs ranged from days to months overdue. According to the program of 
veterinary care all adult dogs must be vaccinated for parvovirus and distemper annually. Not following the written program 
of veterinary care and not maintaining dogs current on required vaccinations can lead to disease and death. The licensee 
must follow their program of veterinary care. 
To be corrected by October 14, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
